Jan 17, 26

Dear Mr. Turner:

Angela and I arrived quite safely and started school on Friday. She is quite satisfied with
and schools, and shall do our very best to satisfy you.

Mr. Perrie, would you please send Mr. McArthur an order to get our coal oil—that is if you supply it—Also an order to buy some saucepans and
a tea-pot for residence, if you please.

I am,
Yours truly,
Eileen Bradhamme.
Ottawa, January 20, 1926.

Dear Miss Prudhomme:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, stating that you began duties on the 15th instant, and that both yourself and Miss Robillard are satisfied with the conditions at the respective schools.

We are requesting Mr. Agent McArthur to supply the sauce pans and tea pot required for the use of the teachers' residence. The Agent has been requested to consult you as to what you require, and to make early purchase of same.

With reference to the coal oil required, I may say that the Department does not furnish supplies of this nature for teachers' residences at day schools. This is part of the supplies which the teachers, themselves, furnish, and I regret, therefore, that the Department cannot grant your request to purchase the coal oil.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Eileen Prudhomme,
Teacher, Chetlain Indian Day School,
St. Regis, Que.
Ottawa, January 20th, 1926.

Sir:

A request has been received from the teacher of the Chetlain and Chenail Schools to be supplied with a few sauce pans and a tea pot for the use of the teachers' residence. Please ascertain what supplies of this nature the teachers require, and arrange for the early purchase of same. You should obtain itemized accounts from the merchant from whom you make the purchase and these you should attach to proper vouchers, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

The teachers have asked that a supply of coal oil be furnished. I may say that we do not provide coal oil for the use of teachers' residences at day schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. C. McArthur, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

St. Regis, June 1926

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

I am very sorry to have to report on the conduct of the teachers at their boarding house.

I rent them their rooms and they are very dirty.

They have been throwing their slop pail over the windows and the dirt is spread all over the snow around the front of the house. People passing by see everything. I have told them not to do that, but they wouldn't listen to me.

They love a slop pail and could easily empty it in the closet, not to throw it around the house.

It's an awful dirty sight around the house and now it's commencing to melt now. Oh it's terrible.

The hallway they have made it their garbage pit throw everything on the floor.

They have been breaking the dishes, knives and broke the bed. Now I have been renting my room to the teachers for about five years and have never found any fault till now, and I'll tell you it's a mean.

The Customs Officer comes to
See the teacher he hitches his horse stallion to the house and 
cuts off the clapboards. I told him to watch and he got 
so mad that he told me I have 
rented my house and have 
nothing to say. I just told 
him that I didn't rent my house 
to all the officers only to teachers. 
Now I had to talk with 
the teachers and told them to 
be clean. She wouldn't look 
at the dirt she made. 
I have also called an 
agent about it and he's there 
for nobody's good. He just 
simply says I don't know. 
He can't help anybody that's 
in trouble. We have a poor agent 
while people laugh at us. 
Well I hope you help me 
to keep the teachers in perfect 
cleanliness and order.

Yours,
Mrs. Christy Sherrard.
St. Regis, Que.
Ottawa, March 15, 1926.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has received a communication, purporting to be signed by Mrs. Christy Sherron, who rents a portion of her home for living quarters for the teachers of the Chetlain and Chenail Indian Day Schools. Our correspondent complains that the teachers are not clean around the residence and that she has reported the matter to you. Please let me know if Mrs. Sherron has complained in this connection and make a report to the Department without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. C. McArthur, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

August 24, 1926.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Official letter of August 30, 1921, indicates that the Sharrons (owners of the house) should provide all furniture and other equipment needed for the teachers' (Chetlain and Chenail) living quarters. Miss Prudhomme, who called at the Department today, states that there is required immediately one double bed, mattress, blankets, linens, pillows, etc.; some cutlery and dishes.

The officer who goes to St. Regis next week should try to arrange with the Sharrons to use the $12 monthly rental for the purpose of securing the equipment that is needed for the teachers. It would then belong to the Sharrons. Miss Prudhomme has given satisfactory reasons why equipment that the Sharrons have used should not be placed in the residence.
Department of Indian Affairs

A.A. Fournelle
Cornwall,
Ontario.

Ottawa, January 20th, 1927.

Sir,

Arrangements were made some time ago for the use of a room in the residence of Mrs. L. Sharrom for the teachers of the Chenail and Chetlain Indian Day Schools. She is allowed rent at the rate of $12.00 a month and, at the end of each month, you should forward a voucher, in duplicate, as per sample attached, in her favour.

Enclosed is a list of the articles in this residence which are the property of the Department. Previous to the summer holidays, it would be well for you to check over this list and see that the articles are properly stored until the teachers return.

An officer of the Department visited the reserve last September and the teachers complained that the stove in the residence was not altogether suitable, especially for cooking purposes. At that time, Sharroms agreed to provide a new stove. It was, also, understood that they would place a proper lock on the door in order that the teachers might close the room while they were absent from the residence. If Sharroms have not already carried out their promises in the above regards, the Department desires that you make immediate arrangements with them to do so.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean.
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,

Ottawa, July 11th, 1927.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 20th ultimo, I have to request that you will arrange to have the bedding, etc., in the teachers' residence in connection with the Chetlain and Chenail Indian Day Schools removed as soon as possible and stored at St. Regis. The Department considers that if these supplies were stored in the teachers' residence at St. Regis there would be the same difficulty as where they are at present, and it is hoped that you can arrange to see that this bedding is placed in secure quarters where it will not be used during the absence of the teachers. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that this bedding is properly looked after until required when the school reopens.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to say regarding teacher's residence, Chenail.
Miss Lagarde, teacher of Chetlain Indian Day School, and who resides at Mrs. L. Sharrons, requests that two Yale locks be placed on the doors of her quarters, one on her bed-room door upstairs, and one on the room downstairs. The reason for this request is, that Miss Lagarde does not wish to have her rooms interfered with, or occupied during her absence from the residence. If I remember right, although I am unable to find anything on file in this matter, that in the year 1927 this same matter was brought up, but the owners of the house objected, assuming that they should be entitled to enter the two rooms in question, during the absence of the teacher to look over the stove, in case of fire.

I am unable to visit Mrs. Sharrons, in the Chenail at present, on account of poor crossing.

Kindly advise me if you recommend the placing of these two locks, if so, authorize me in purchasing locks and placing them.

Ottawa, July 23rd, 1930.

Sir:

Miss Legarde, teacher of the Chetlain Indian Day School, visited the Department yesterday and requested that locks be installed on two doors in the teachers' living quarters in the house which is rented from Mrs. L. Charron as a teachers' residence. She states that during her absence outsiders enter her rooms and that she has had certain clothing, etc., taken.

I have to request that you will arrange, before the schools reopen, to have a good, strong lock installed on each door. Each lock should be supplied with two keys, which should be handed to the teacher when she returns. After the locks have been installed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of same and the labour in having them put on.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, in which you report that Miss Legarde, teacher of the Chetlain Indian Day School, is not satisfied with the room that has been rented for her for living quarters.

The Department does not consider that it would be advisable for Miss Legarde to live in the residence at St. Regis Village. This is a considerable distance from the Chetlain School, and even though she were driven to the school, it is doubtful if she could conveniently reach Chetlain School in time to begin duties at nine o'clock, especially during the winter months.

Please see Mrs. Sharron, and if you cannot make satisfactory arrangements with her for suitable living quarters for Miss Legarde, you should endeavour to obtain living accommodation for the teacher at some other residence near the Chetlain School. For the amount allowed by the Department, it is considered that it should be possible to obtain proper accommodation for the teacher.

Dear Sir:

It is noted from your letter of the 10th instant that the residence in which Miss Legarde was living was destroyed by fire.

When Miss Legarde visited the Department a few weeks ago it was understood that she was aware of another house where she could obtain accommodation. The Director,

R. A. Hoey, Esq., Superintendent of Welfare & Training.

Prior to closing of the Chetlain School, the teacher advised me she had experienced difficulty with the drainage system in her residence for the past three years, and that the cellar drain installed a couple of years ago in the residence basement never took the water out of the cellar.

It is an expensive proposition to get a plumber to go to that district so I went down today with an Indian to see if we could clear up the trouble in the residence drainage from the sink and bathtub. I find this system constitutes a 1/4" pipe from the sink and bath connection on a "Y" in the cellar and along the cellar floor through the foundation wall. On the outside stones are laid to a cesspool to carry off the water. I could not get the outside line opened today but from Indians that were around when the system was installed they told me the piping ends at the outside of the cement wall of the foundation.

There is not even one union in the cellar where the piping can be broken to clear the pipes but by removing the bathtub connections I was able to get a stout wire down the piping and as this was knotted at intervals on the end, I managed to clear the sludge from the pipes inside the building.

The stones will have to be removed outside, as they must be all fallen in and a suitable drain-off outside the building made. I am hopeful that a new cesspool need not be made, and unless unforeseen circumstances arise, this work can be finished with small cost.

I will not attempt the cellar drainage system which was installed a couple of years ago and never worked unless you want the work undertaken. There will be a labour cost here of at least $100.00. This should be done, however, as it is impossible for the teacher to get any coal out of her cellar during March and April and part of May, due to the depth of water in the cellar. I might say that considerable rot is taking place here as well.

T. L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.

R. A. Hoey, Esq., Superintendent, Mines & Training.

Further to my letter of July 20 concerning the drainage system in the teacher's residence at the Chetlain Indian Day School. Under separate cover, voucher #168 in the amount of $4.90 is going forward which represents cost of labour so far on this job.

I might say that in order to get the system working freely from the sink and bath in the residence, the drain was dug up to the cesspool. It was found, after digging the drain, that the 1¼" pipe ran through into the cesspool and not as previously advised. Rocks were removed in the cesspool to the level of the drain pipe and it was possible then to clear out all obstructions in the system. It was noted, however, that the cesspool is not working very good and there does not appear to be any sump whatever with the result that the water and sludge piles in the pool and backs up into the system. The attached sketch will show the approximate layout of this drainage system.

I believe the only way that we will be able to get satisfaction would be to install another cellar drain running out on the north side of the building towards the gradual slope of the land. The drainage from the bath and sink could be connected up in the cellar onto the system or it might be possible to have the drain off from the cesspool connecting with a "Y" outside onto the cellar drain. This would keep the water level down in the cesspool eliminating any blocking of the 1¼" pipe drain.

I would not consider it advisable or economical to re-open the cellar drain which was installed a couple of years ago as this drain runs uphill towards higher ground instead of running out the north side of the building and following the natural slope. It will cost us approximately $100. for labour to put in a new line coming out the north side of the building. If this were done, I would block up the other cellar drain and remove the trap and install it in a more suitable location in the cellar. This will, however, be an additional expenditure for glazed and field tile but I do not expect this will run much above $20. Until I hear from you I am leaving the present cesspool open and it would be appreciated if you could forward your reply without delay.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 15th inst., I must say that the altitude has not been as high as you stated. The severe cold and storms that we have had have caused the thermometer to register as low as fifteen degrees below zero, and then the snow has drifted so much that nearly all roads are blocked. It has been impossible for the children living any distance from the school to attend. The children who have been at school seem delighted with...
the idea and are more willing to work.

I am sure that there will be a great improvement in the attitude and cooperation this month.

I do not think that the meal will cost more than seven dollars a month, that is counting on an average attendance of eighteen children. I shall let you know when I have used the supply on hand how many meals I have supplied with the ten dollar order. I do not give them a full meal but a few biscuits and tea, and then either boiled rice, peas or beans.

Your obedient servant,

GENERAL REMARKS.

The children are often kept at home to work, also in stormy and wet weather, and when the roads get bad. Since the Department has been supplying material for sewing the attendance has increased considerably and the children take much more interest in their work. The mid-day meal has also been an inducement for them to come to school. I think that we should have swings, lats, balls and skipping ropes for the children. These poor children have very little happiness and sunshine in their homes and I think it would smarten them to have such things to play with, as well as making their school interesting to them.

Sir,

Miss White, teacher of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School, in her annual report to the Department, states that owing to the distance which the children live from the school, insufficient clothing and lack of interest on the part of the parents, the attendance is very irregular and would be improved if the annual holidays were taken during the winter and teach in the summer.

It is considered that owing to the above reasons this plan regarding holidays should receive a trial at this school. If you consider it advisable you may instruct the teacher to close the school until after the Easter holidays and she should resume duties again on April 8th, next. Sir,

In a report on his inspection of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School on the 2nd ultimo, Mr. Inspector Maltais states as follows:

"Almost without exception, pupils of this school are very irregular in attending school. Such a condition has existed in the last few years. A reward of some kind to those who would attend school a minimum number of days of the year might prove a great incentive towards a better attendance."

Sirs:

Referring to your letter of the 10th ultimo, No. 18-1-1, concerning the attendance at Congo Bridge school, I beg to inform you that I have had an interview with the teacher Miss White, and she concurs with the report of the Inspector Mr. Maltais, that the work of the pupils is far from satisfactory, but she says that she is doing all she can possibly to stimulate their ambition, but without any noticeable results.

I have myself often tried to make them read louder or in a comprehensible manner, but always to no avail, they do not seem to pay attention to remarks made to them.

Concerning the lack of attendance, in most cases the parents will not insist on their children going to school, and when you ask them why such a boy or girl is going to school, their ordinary answer is "He knows the road to school, he can go if he wants to."

The troublesome dispositions of some of the Indians during the last few years also contribute to this lack of attendance, as some families are keeping their children from attending.

December 30, 1935.

Dear Mr. Perras:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, with reference to the appointment of a teacher at the Congo Bridge Indian Day School. The former teacher of the Maniwaki Indian Day School was obliged to give up duties in September last, owing to illness, and a temporary teacher was appointed. Subsequent information showed that the regular teacher was not prepared to resume duties, and, as the temporary teacher was not fully qualified, the question arose at the end of November regarding what provision should be made for teaching services at the Maniwaki and Congo Bridge Schools for the term beginning January 6th, next.

As Miss Freda White, the present teacher at the Congo Bridge School, had been in our employ for many years and reports showed that she was doing good work, the Department decided that it was only fair to promote her to the Maniwaki Indian Day School.

To succeed Miss White at the Congo Bridge School, several applications were considered, and we believed that Miss Rita Somers, who has a second class professional certificate and has had six years' experience, was the best qualified among the applicants, and she was, therefore, appointed by official letter of November 27th to take charge of the Congo Bridge School on January 6th.

The appointment of teachers of Indian day schools rests with the Department of Indian Affairs, and we have always endeavoured to secure the services of the best qualified teachers, without any consideration as to their place of residence at the time of appointment. The Department

F. W. Perras, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
is endeavouring to supply for Indian schools teachers who are well qualified, and, when a teacher's services do not prove satisfactory, it has always been the practice of the Department to try someone else. I feel you will agree that this is the only manner in which schools can be properly operated. Recognition of this fact has, no doubt, influenced succeeding Ministries in leaving the appointment and dismissal of teachers of Indian day schools to the permanent officials, who endeavour to the best of their ability to supply qualified teaching service.

As I have pointed out in the first part of this letter, Miss Somers has already been appointed and she has accepted the position requiring her to open the school next week. Without specific directions from the Honourable the Superintendent General to the contrary, the Department does not feel that her appointment should be cancelled.

I note that you now recommend Miss McSheffrey. I am directing the officers of the Schools Branch to keep her in mind whenever a vacancy occurs. I would appreciate Miss McSheffrey writing me stating her age, religion and qualifications.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

FORM 14
Ottawa, Nov. 26th, 1924.

Madam:

The Department understands that you consider there is a balance due for your services as teacher of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School for the past school year. Previous to September 1, 1923, salaries to teachers in Indian day schools were paid on a quarterly basis, that is, your salary for the year was paid in four payments of equal amount at the end of each quarter. From September 1, 1923, the method of payment of salaries to teachers was changed to a monthly basis of ten teaching months in the year. For the quarter ended September 30, 1923, you, having taught the month of September only, were paid one month's salary. For the quarter ended December 31st, 1923, you were paid salary for the months of October, November and December, and again at the end of March and June you received three months' salary for each of these periods, thus completing your full salary for the school year - September 1, 1923, to June 30th, 1924. Each school year begins on the 1st of September and ends on June 30th, comprising a period of ten months. You will receive three months' salary at the end of each of the following periods, viz., December 31st, 1924, March 31st and June 30th, 1925.

If you will examine the method of payment since September 1st, 1923, you will find that you have been paid salary in full to the end of September, last. If any further explanation is required by you the same will be furnished upon your request.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Helen J. White,
Teacher, Congo Bridge Indian Day School,
River Desert, Que.

Ottawa, August 9, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the application of Miss Florence McCauley for the position as teacher of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School for the next school year.

In reply I have to say that, in view of your recommendation, the Department will approve of the appointment of Miss McCauley for the next school year. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $60 per teaching month. Please advise her of her appointment and arrange with her to begin duties when the school reopens after the present summer holidays, on September 3rd, next.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, P.Q.

Ottawa, October 4, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is allowing Miss Florence McCauley, teacher of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School, an increase of $10 per teaching month in her salary from the 1st of September, last. This will make the total salary allowed her from that date at the rate of $70 per teaching month. This increase is made in view of the fact that Miss McCauley is purchasing a horse for her own use in travelling to and from school each day. She has been informed of the increase in salary allowed her.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E. S. Gauthier, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Maniwaki, Que.

OTTAWA, 1st September, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent McCaffrey forwards a resolution from the River Desert Band asking for funds to build a schoolhouse near the Congo Bridge out of the capital funds of their Band.

These Indians have a school on the Desert Road about 2½ miles south of the village. The locality where they wish to put up a new schoolhouse and where a number of Indians reside, (The Agent stating that there are 23 children who could attend the school) is over 7 miles from the school now in operation and over 4 miles from the village, and the children are thus cut off from receiving an education.

The accompanying sketch of the Maniwaki reserve contains a list of the Indians with the lots on which they are located. They are divided into three settlements; one on the Gatineau Road, one on the Gatineau River east of the village and the other on the Desert River near the Congo Bridge.

Some of the children on the Gatineau river settlement attend the white school in the village, while others occasionally go to the Gatineau Road Indian school, while the Indians near the Congo Bridge, as before stated, have no opportunity of going to school.

The River Desert Band has about $28,000 to
their credit and pays all expenses in connection with their present school. Their capital would stand the cost of another school building, which could be put up and equipped for about $700.00, but at their present rate of expenditure their interest would not, I think, stand the teacher's salary. If the Department decided to allow them to build a school it would have to provide the greater portion of the salary at least.

A similar application was made some two years ago, when the question of salary proved the stumbling block.

Specification for the erection of proposed Indian School-House and Out-Buildings, and the laying out of the School Grounds at Congo Bridge, Desert River, Maniwaki, Que.

Description

The school-house building is to be a one-story frame structure on a stone foundation built in accordance with the accompanying drawings.

Foundation

Dig a trench (see plan of grounds for the location of the building) to receive the foundation for the walls of the school-room, cloak-room and shed, two feet deep and two feet wide, and hand lay a dry wall 20 inches thick to the level of the ground, upon this wall build with fair sized buildings stones a mason wall, well bonded, 18 inches high and not less than 16 inches thick.

Dig three pits 2 X 2 X 2 feet deep and at seven feet centres, as shown on the plan and build piers in a similar manner to the walls.

The earth is to be well rammed against the walls and piers to ground level.

Ventilators

Provide and place five common iron ventilators in the outside walls of the building, three on the southerly and two on the front elevation.

Chimney

The footing stone of the chimney is to be 6 inches thick. Build chimney of hard burnt brick and cement mortar, full joint. Brick to commence at top of mason wall. Build in the chimney from bottom to top a 12 inch diameter, 1/16 inch thick galvanized iron smoke stack, to be securely jointed together, and held to the side of the chimney shaft. The bottom of the smoke stack is to empty into a scot box, which is to be provided with a door opening say 18 inches above floor, on the cloak-room side of the chimney.
Chimney

Provide and place a large ventilating register, at least two square feet of surface, on the school-room side of the chimney at the bottom of the wainscoting.

Put in thimble and stopper for stove pipe

Sills, Joists

Wall plates 2 X 8 inches well bedded with mortar. Girder under centre of floor 6 X 8 inches; floor joists 2 X 10 inches at 16 inch centres. Put two rows of herring bone bridging of 2 X 2 inch stuff, well nailed between the outside walls and the centre girder.

Walls

The studding to be 2 X 4 inch stuff doubled at the corners, and windows and door-frames, well braced with two rows of braces. Wall plates double 2 X 4 inches, and doubled over windows and door openings.

The outside of walls to be first sheeted on the outside with 1 inch rough boards, put on diagonally close jointed and well nailed, and fitted closely to the windows and door frames; and then to be sheeted with 1 inch clapboards 5 inches wide, one ply of 12 oz. tar paper, well lapped, is to be laid between the above sheeting and clapboards.

The inside of the outer walls of the shed is to be rough boarded.

Roofing

The rafters are to be 2 X 6 inch at 2 feet centres. Hip rafters 2 X 7 inches. The rafters of cloak room and shed to be 2 X 5 inches, 2 feet centres. The tie beams of roof to be 2 X 6 inch, and 16 feet long, 2 feet centres. Belfry roof rafters 2 X 4 inch. All rafters to be properly framed and well spiked down.

Cover the several roofs with rough boarding, closely laid and well nailed to the rafters,
and lay one ply of heavy tar paper over same, well lapped, and shingle with best sawn cedar shingles, dipped in Cabot's Green Creosote Shingle stain (Seymour & Co., Montreal) 4 1/2 inches to the weather finish roof with weather boards and roll complete. Lay tar paper under the eyes before sheeting.

Wainscoting

The walls of the school-room are to be wainscoted 3 feet-6 inches high with narrow beaded sheathing. Finish with cap and Scotia and put quarter round at floor. The walls of the cloak-room are to be wainscoted to a height of 6 feet.

Doors and windows

Provide and hang with 3 - 4 inch butts the four doors shown on the plan. Inside doors to be four panelled 1 3/4 inches thick, 7 feet high and 4 feet wide. To have rebated frames 2 1/2 inches thick. Provide and fix best 6 inch American locks to entrance and school-room doors, with two keys to each, and suitable furniture. Shed door to have outside a good padlock and to hook inside. Put 7/8 inch thick oak thresholds at all outside doors and school-room door. The windows will be of the size and number shown on the plan. The frames to be fitted with 1 3/4 inch pine double sliding lip sash hung and properly balanced with weights and heavy Silver Lake Sash cord.

The whole of the windows to be fitted with 1 1/2 inch winter sashes. Winter sashes to be divided into same number of lights as permanent sash with pane (the bottom middle) in hardwood frame arranged to slide horizontally. Winter sashes to be provided with strong hooks and eyes.

Wooden Shutters

The windows of school-room are to have outside wooden shutters of narrow vertical sheeting and to be hung in two leaves over the window sashes, and shuttered and fit all necessary window lifts and window carry simple architraves at least 5 inches wide around windows and doors.
Floors

All floors, except shed floor, are to be double, the lower one being of rough boards laid close and well nailed. The upper floor is to laid with 7/8 inch tongued and grooved hardwood or selected pine flooring in narrow widths and blind nailed. Put a layer of heavy sheathing paper between the two floorings. The finished floor is not to be laid until after the plastering is done.

Floor the part of the shed where marked on the plan with 2 inch plank, floor to be carried on 2 x 10 inch joists laid at 16 inch centres.

The veranda floor and steps to be floored with 1 1/8 inch yellow pine tongued and grooved, flooring in narrow widths, laid with paint between joints.

The floor of the belfry is to be covered with galvanized iron.

Platform

A platform is to made on the floor of the school-room where shown on the plan. Joists 2 x 6 inches at 16 inch centres, and floored same as school floor. Put on facing board and nosing complete.

Closet and Book Shelves

Build in a simple cloak closet, with one shelf, 7 feet high, and a book shelf with four shelves as shown on the plan. Height of book-shelf to be 4 feet from the platform.

Closet to have lock and key.

Lath and Plastering

Lath and plaster the whole of the walls and ceiling of the school and cloak rooms, not otherwise specified. Plaster with two coats and hard finish.

The first two coats to be carried behind the wainscoting, architraves, etc.

Blackboard

Provide and put in place above the wainscoting, at the back of the platform a framed blackboard 3 1/2 feet
Blackboard by 10 feet of "Compo Slate Blackboard" or other approved material.

Belfry Build a simple belfry as drawn on the drawing. The ceiling under belfry is to have a 2 x 2 ft. trap door with a suitable register framed into it. Lay on walk of 2 inch plank, 2 feet wide and 6 feet long from both sides of this trap-door across the ceiling joists.

Provide and place a bell to cost complete $5. The rope from the bell is to be carried on pulleys over the ceiling and to enter the cloak-room in the chimney recess near the entrance from the porch.

Clothes hooks Provide and fix three dozen clothes hooks on the walls of the cloak-room. Hooks to be in two rows of 4 and 5 feet above the floor and staggered.

Painting Knot, prime, stop and paint in two coat work the whole of the wood-work, not otherwise specified. The outside wood-work to be painted with white lead and linseed oil in two colours, light brown with dark brown facings.

Glaze all lights with clear medium heavy glass.

Water closets The water closets two in number are to be built in accordance with the accompanying drawing. (cedar) Dig soil pits and timber the same as shown. The lattice is to be of strips 3 X 1/2 planed and painted green.

Paint the outside in two coat work, same as school building, and white-wash the walls and roof inside.

The roof to be shingled with best cedar shingles, 4 1/2 inches to the weather.

Fence Build a 7 foot close boarded fence from the
school room to the rear fence line of the play-ground.

The sides rear and front of the school ground are to be enclosed with Page fencing 19-Bar-57 inch—25 cents per rod to be carried on straight cedar posts, 8 inches in diameter and 9 feet long, 4 feet in the ground, and at 20 feet centres. Properly brace the corner posts according to the directions sent with this fencing.

Provide and set two Single Page Gates, 57 inches high and 4 1/2 and 10 feet wide, the former to be the entrance gate to the school, the latter the side gate leading to the boys' play-ground.

Grade the school ground and lay out the gravel walks, sow with grass seed the front lawn, and the girls' playground. Plant maple or local saplings where shown. All to be done in accordance with the accompanying plan of the grounds and outbuildings.

Give a separate price complete for each of the following:

1. School-house building
2. Water closets
3. Fencing
4. Leaving out of School grounds.

The whole of the work to be executed in a thoroughly workmanlike manner, and subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent, or other officer who may be appointed for the purpose.
Ottawa, 26th November, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent McCaffrey forwards under date of the 3rd instant, four tenders for the erection of a new schoolhouse near Congo Bridge on the Desert River, Maniwaki in accordance with the plans and specifications sent him on the 26th November last. Mr Jos. Lavasseur offers to do the work for $3595.00
Mr W.L. Ecuyer will do it for ........... $1676.36
Mr Anastase Roy will do it for .......... $3150.00

All these tenders exceed the amount originally contemplated to be expended for this purpose by nearly $1000.00, while the lowest tender is, according to Mr McCaffrey's estimate, nearly $1000.00 short of the amount figured out by him.

If the Department considers that the funds of the Band could stand Mr Ecuyer's offer of $1676.36 and he is prepared to furnish security for the due fulfilment of his contract, his offer is by far the best and should be accepted.

MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Supt. General of I.A.

In the matter of this new school for the Indians of Congo Bridge, Maniwaki, I think we should go back to the first principles as soon as possible.

The School house which we erected on this Reserve about 5 years ago cost us (completed and furnished) about $700.00. It is an ordinary frame school house, 18 x 24' and meets all the needs of the case. It is impossible to find funds for the school house to cost $1,676.36; and in any event it would be a profligate expenditure for that district. There is no reason why the Indian School there should be any better than the ordinary white schools throughout the Gatineau region, they are frame and log buildings. I therefore recommend that we use our ordinary plan and abandon the present scheme which is beyond our means or requirements.

Accountant.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

If the school is to be built no time should be lost in commencing operations so that it will be ready for occupation after the summer holidays. Mr. Benson & Co.

Dear Sir,

In regard to a fence for the garden, the Indians do not care to make any kind except a wire. They will supply the posts if the Department supplies the wire. Ordinary fence wire can be had here for three dollars and fifty cents per hundred pounds. I do not think it would take a hundred pounds to fence the garden. Some of the Indians were clear up around the school on Saturday, and they said that if the Department would supply the wire...
They would fence in about an acre around the school. Then they could plow and level off the ground and sow grass seed. I think if we had the wire for the fence, for the garden, you could set about the other things so when the Indians would not be so busy.

Mr. Benson, how about the dumb-bells and food stuff? Do you think the Department will supply them? The floods have started up here. I think they will be as bad as last year.

Yours Truly,

Rose H. Gilhooley
River Desert
Quebec.

Chaque classe doit être pourvue de deux ventilateurs permanents, qui courent généralement dans les murs. Ces tuyaux, en tôle galvanisée, doivent partir, l'un à 24 pouces du plancher, l'autre à 18 pouces du plafond. Celui qui part à 24 pouces du plancher monte directement au-dessus du toit dans une fausse cheminée construite à cet effet. Celui qui part à 18 pouces du plafond rejoint l'autre à un angle de 40 degrés où il est bien soude. Le diamètre de ces tuyaux est proportionné à la grandeur de la classe.

Il vaut mieux placer les lieux d'aisances en dehors du hangar lorsque celui-ci est adossé à la maison d'école. Il est désirable, dans ce cas, de relier le hangar aux lieux d'aisances par un passage de 12 pieds de long, fermé, éclairé par deux petites fenêtres, l'une vis-à-vis de l'autre et pouvant s'ouvrir à volonté, et pourvu d'un ventilateur au plafond. Les ventilateurs des lieux d'aisances doivent partir de dessous les sièges et urinoirs, et sortir par la couverture.

Un diamètre de trois pouces serait suffisant dans le cas actuel.

A. H. Fillan
Ventilation of School Buildings

Each class-room ought to be provided with two permanent ventilators, which run generally in the walls. These pipes, in galvanized iron, should start, one at 24 inches from the floor, the other at 18 inches from the ceiling. The one starting at 24 inches from the floor rises directly above the roof in a false chimney built for that purpose. The one starting at 18 inches from the ceiling joins the other at an angle of 40 degrees, where it is well soldered. The diameter of these pipes is in proportion to the size of the class.

It is best to place the water-closets outside of the shed when the latter is attached to the school-house. It is desirable in such case to connect the shed with the water-closets by a passage 12 feet long, closed in, lighted by two small windows, opposite each other and able to be opened at will, and provided with a ventilator in the ceiling. The ventilators of the water-closets ought to start from under the seats and urinals and go out by the roof.

A diameter of 3 inches would be sufficient in the present case.

A.M. Filteau

Maniwaki, October 2nd, 1931.

Sir;-

According to Dept. letter of July 6th, 1931, No. 18-2-5, I have had repairs made to the Maniwaki School building and furniture as follows:-

1° The walls of school and porch covered over with fiber board.
2° One coat of filling to fiber board and two coats of paint to dado and ceiling.
3° Building platform and steps at entrance of building.
4° Banking around foundation with earth.
5° Repairs made to chimney.
6° Putting up new desks.
7° Repairing 7 desks and one coat of paint to 13 old desks.
8° Placing stove in rear corner of building and protecting walls or building with galvanized metal made up with air spaces between walls and metal.
9° Repair on school shutter.
10° Replacing 3 panes of glass.
11° Placing clothes hooks in porch.
12° Repair to door lock.
13° Painting black boards two coats.

Referring to the few repairs made, who were not mentioned on the authorization, I beg to say that the amount is not very considerable, for instance, seven desks were broken and new pieces had to be added to the desks or tables, so this new work had to be painted. I thought advisable to give a coat of paint to all the old desks.

The black board were peeled in different places, and by giving two coats of paint they are now in good order.

9 broken panes of glass were replaced.

I also thought advisable to install some clothes hooks in the porch.

The stove the way we have it fixed now will add comfort to the pupils. I had to protect the walls with galvanized metal 5 inches away from the wood, also additional pipes had to be procured, as the stove is now further away from the chimney.

Trusting the above mentioned repairs will meet the approval of the Department.

SIR:

Miss Florence McAuley, teacher at the Congo Bridge School, is using a horse to go to her school, and there is no place near the school to keep the horse out of the cold.

There is an old wood shed 10'x12" but it is beyond state of repair, it is about falling down, even if it could be repaired to use it as a stable the cost would be $65.00 or $70.00 and yet be too large for lodging one horse and not large enough to use part of it for a wood shed.

Therefore it would be better to build a wood shed 12' x 24' at one end of it a stall six feet wide could be made warm for the horse, and the other part 12' x 18' could be used for a wood shed, my estimate for this building is approximately $150.00 to $150.00.

If the Department decides to supply a stable for the horse I recommend the building of shed as above described.

Ottawa, October 24, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, regarding the request of the teacher of the Congo Bridge Indian Day School, that stabling be provided for a horse, which she uses in travelling to and from her work as teacher at that point.

In reply I have to say the Department approves of your recommendation, that it would be better to build a woodshed, 12 ft. x 24 ft., at one end of which a stall, 6 ft. wide, could be provided for stabling the horse. You may arrange for the purchase of the quantity of lumber and other materials required and for the erection of a woodshed, as soon as possible. This building should contain a stall suitable for stabling the teacher's horse. The cost of this building, including material and labour, should not exceed the sum of $140. Purchase of the materials should be made from firms on the list to receive consideration and the work, as far as possible, should be done by Indian labour.

I enclose encumbrance certificate, authorizing an expenditure to the above mentioned amount. You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of all materials. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. Further, please keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, for the labour employed. These should also be certified by you and forwarded for payment.

Please see that a satisfactory job is completed in the erection of this woodshed and that all costs are kept to the lowest possible point. In forwarding the vouchers for payment of materials and labour, you should state on each copy that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. No. 1069.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, January 20, 1934.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding a resolution of the River Desert Band, requesting that midday meals be supplied to the children attending the Congo Bridge and Maniwaki Indian Day Schools during the months of February, March and April, next.

In reply I have to say that, owing to the crowded condition of the schools and lack of space to prepare and serve the meal and also as it is understood that any Indians requiring assistance are receiving relief, and further, as our funds are extremely limited, the Department is not prepared to authorize the expense incurred in furnishing the supplies for the purpose.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter dated July the 18th in regard to the Report made by the School Inspector Gagnon to painting the inside of the Congo Bridge Day School.

I am positive that Mr. Gagnon made a mistake as it was the outside of that school that needs paint and not the inside. The inside was painted but a few years ago.

To my estimation the painting of that school would cost about $75.00 to $100.00 comprising labour and paint. This also would include the steeple which is hardly anything, the repairs to the steeple could also be made for the amount stated as I figure that around $2.00 to $3.00 would repair it.

Dear Sir:

Re: Painting & repairs Congo Bridge School.

I have your letter of July the 31st, asking if the estimation of $75.00 to $100.00 would be comprising the material and labour for painting the Congo Bridge Day School. I wish to inform you that I have inquired from different Indians about painting this School and find Mr. Noel Chalifoux, Band No. 234 willing to take the job of painting and furnishing the paint for the amount of $85.00. Naturally this work would consist of scraping the old paint with a fiber brush wherever it would need it and apply after two coats of paint.

There would be also two base boards holding the clapboards to renew as they are rotten and clapboard the steeple as recommended by inspector Gagnon. This in all cannot cost more than $7. or $8.

To be absolutely sure of everything I would say that $100.00 would cover everything that is labour, paint, material and repairs. It may cost a little less and if it does the money will be returned to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am returning you herein return of labour ending September the 2nd, 1939.

R.M. Gendron's account for furnishing material is duly receipted as asked. It is almost impossible to mark the exact time for this work as it was given by job to Mr. Noel Chalifoux and the exact labour of every day was not kept. I can say though that Mr. Noel Chalifoux' account for paint, oil, brush etc., at Anastase Roy amounted to $34.26. He had therefore an amount of $50.74 that was paid in wages to him and his Indian employees, which I think were mostly his boys. Before giving this job to Mr. Chalifoux I interviewed Mr. Ashenbault painter of Maniwaki, who had previously done this job for the Indian Department and his price was $75.00, but with the wood work Mr. Chalifoux had to do, I considered the price of $85.00 very satisfactory.

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I visited the Congo Bridge Day School today with Miss Rosetta Laflour and also tried to find a boarding house.

The only decent place where a school teacher can board there is at Mrs. Joe Chalifoux and they have answered us that they would prefer not taking the school teacher to board this year. If the teacher cannot board there, I do not see another place where she could board and Miss Laflour was inquiring if the Department would not build a small place next to the school house where she could live and cook her own meals.

To my estimation a small place like that would cost around $600, and I do not know if the Department would be in a position to build one or not. Naturally there is no doubt that it is very much needed and would be a great advantage to the teachers.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
September 25, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letters of the 20th instant in connection with the Congo Bridge Indian Day School.

Unless Miss Lafleur is able to obtain boarding accommodation the school will have to remain closed as the Department has no funds available for the erection of a teacher's residence.

In the event of her securing boarding accommodation and opening the school it should be distinctly understood that her employment is only temporary as we will expect her to forward satisfactory proofs that she is a British Subject. If unable to do this she should take immediate steps to become naturalized.

You should advise me later whether or not Miss Lafleur opens the school.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Re: Lots 34 or 35 Range 7 Maniwaki Reserve.

The Congo Bridge Day School is built on one of the two above mentioned lots.

To-day while visiting this School I noticed that Mr. Jos Chalifoux' boys had chopped the nice birch trees that are around the School and even felled them right in the School yard.

When this School was built was there a piece of land bought for its location, if so Mr. Chalifoux must be immediately stopped from chopping down those trees as it is spoiling the sight of that School completely and even making dangerous for fire as those branches will be left there to rot and make it very easy to set fires when they are dried off. Kindly look into the matter right away and let me know what can be done.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Mr. J.E. Gendron, Indian Agent, Maniwaki, Que.

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to transporting children living on Bitobee Lake Road and Congway Road to the Congo Bridge Indian Day School.

Please let me know how many children would be affected. Have any of the parents transportation which could be used?

Our experience on other reserves with regard to driving Indian children to school has not been satisfactory. It appears almost impossible to arrange a time that will suit everybody. You can realize that when anyone is transporting pupils they have to start early enough to reach the school before 9 o'clock. This means that those living farthest from the school have to be ready much earlier than those living somewhat closer. As stated above, this appears to be a very difficult matter to properly arrange. With our former experience I am doubtful if the expenditure that would be necessary in carrying out this suggestion would be justified. However, a final decision will not be made until we hear further from you.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Maniwaki, August the 7th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Referring to your letter of June the 16th, 1944, concerning a resolution passed by the Indians of the River Desert asking the Department to organize in order to pick up the children living too far away to go to School.

I would estimate 35 to 40 children would be living too far away from School to go, this would comprise the Bitobee road where there is not School on that road and where there is approximately 20 children of the School age. Would this system be a success, should we be able to organize it, is something more than I can say and no doubt a lot would not come to School just the same. I would suggest that such a scheme be let go till the war is over and then may be at that time a bus could be acquired for such a scheme. I do not know of any one on the Reserve which would have an outfit to take those children to School, in the Winter with the organization we have and the roads blocked with snow, only a team of horses could be used and a lot of those children would be late for School. It is too bad to see that some of those families are unable to send their children to School on account of living too far, but I am at a lost to know how the situation can be remedied.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 9, 1944.

Mr. J.E. Gendron, Indian Agent, Maniwaki, Que.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, in further reference to driving certain Indian children of the River Desert Band, who are living too far away to attend school regularly. Under the circumstances I feel that the matter should be allowed to stand for the present.

Philip Phelan,

In answer to your letter of July the 5th, 1947, concerning the building of the above house, I wish to include you the estimates prepared by myself and the carpenter who is supposed to build this house.

As you see by these estimates the cost of installing a pump and a sink in the kitchen, also the drain pipes are not included, for the simple reason, that it might be hard to pump water where that house will be located, as it will be built on a hill.

Last year I had put in an estimate of $2000. to build that house, but since the material has kept going up and in order not to be disappointed I would say that we would go nearer to $3500. than $2000. to finish this house. It may be possible that it would not cost us exactly that amount, but we will not be far from it.

Will you kindly let me know what you intend that I should spend on the Maniwaki Indian Day School, the well has already cost us $780.00 adding $3500. for the Congo Bridge house, that will make $4280. Putting in the lights the toilets, pump, wash basins, stairs etc. etc., in the Maniwaki Indian Day School will cost quite a bit and I am working on those estimates and as soon as they are ready I will let you know what they are, but at a first glance I am sure they will cost
$4,000. to $5,000., thus making a total expenditure of about $8,500. to $9,000. for the two schools. Naturally there would be no need to put in a pressure tank if we do not put in the electricity and as I always said before I do not like to go over my estimates in a project of that kind and this year especially it is quite hard to estimate anything.

Work at the Congo Bridge Indian Day School can be started at any time and we have all the material here in Maniwaki to go ahead with this project, but I certainly would like to do what we had intended doing at the Maniwaki Indian Day School as it is very badly needed to improve the situation there.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent:

Maniwaki, September the 4th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,

Re: repairs to Maniwaki Indian Day School
and building at Congo Bridge Ind. Day School.

Already I have received an advance
of $500. on the labour for the repairs to the Maniwaki In-
dian Day School and $500. for the labour on the Congo Bridge
Indian Bay School.

At the Maniwaki Indian Day School
the Cess Pit is all built and connected and the partitions
in the cellar, as well as the stairs are nearly all comple-
ted and it is expected that by next Saturday there will be
very little wood work to be done there, except the plumbing
and painting. The electricity at that School is also nearly
finished and we are waiting on the carpenters to finish up
the cellar as far as electricity is concerned. The power has
not yet been brought in by the Gatineau Power, but the Manager
has promised me a couple of days ago that he would look after
this soon. On this job already an amount of $258.97 have been
paid up to last Saturday on labour and timber furnished by the
Indians. I would therefore need a further advance of another
$500. on that job and would you please see that it is sent as
soon as possible.

In regard to the Congo Bridge Indian
Day School the cellar is dug, the small Cess Pit for that School,
the gravel and the stones are drawn for the cellar. In fact
an amount of $357.50 has already been paid on that job and I
therefore would need a further advance of $500. on that job too.
The full amount paid out up to Friday August the 29th. on both schools is $616.47.

The work is now progressing rapidly and the Carpenters are to start on the Congo Bridge Indian Day School by next Monday.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Re: Construction of Residence at Congo Bridge Indian Day School.

This is to inform you that at the moment the above construction is stopped as it is impossible to get sufficient cement for the foundation.

I had purchased 175 bags of cement for that purpose, but unfortunately the furnisher sold some of this cement thinking that as soon as a car load came in he would give it back, but no cement has yet come this month and none might come before the 1st of October. I tried all over to get some but without satisfaction and I am wondering if it would not be possible to get 50 bags in Ottawa and have it shipped by a transport to Maniwaki. Only for this our house would have been finished for the first of October, except the painting. The footings for the foundation are made and I have on hand 85 bags of cement, but it is not enough for that foundation. If we cannot secure any cement I doubt very much if it will be possible to go ahead with this house before the first shipment of cement which might come in October sometime.

J.E. Gendron,
Indian Agent.

Miss Geraldine Hogan, Teacher at the Congo Bridge Indian Day School advises me that she still needs the following articles for the house there:

- 1 Alladin Lamp
- 1 Mop
- 1 Boiler
- 1 2 gal. Coal-oil Can
- 1 Chamber pail.

We had an alladin lamp at the Maniwaki Indian Day School which we do not use now that the electricity has been installed. I could get this lamp repaired and give it to her. Miss Hogan had asked for a 5 gal coal-oil can, but I believe a 2 gal. can would be sufficient.

As for the other articles, they could all be obtained locally if this is suitable to the Department.

J.E. Gendron,

Sir,

I have the honor to call attention to some facts concerning the Indian schools on the St Regis Reserve, and especially Cornwall Island. In a letter received from the Rev. E. Tennant, Missionary in charge, he writes as follows respecting the change made when the two schools were supposed to be consolidated in one:

"On Sunday after the service I spoke to the parents about sending their children, and had old Mr Benedict explain the matter, as he had it direct from the Agent. For a little while only a few of the Protestant children attended. But lately there is not one child from our people going. I enquired into the matter, and find it difficult to get all the facts in the case. There is an unwillingness on the part of our people to have their children go. They tell me the Catholic children are very rough and profane. One man said it took several days to break his little boy from the habit of swearing, and said that he would send his children no more to that school.

"As the matter stands now only the Catholic children are attending the school. However, seven Protestants have been sent away to the Industrial schools, some to Brantford, and others to Muncey, and there are others wanting to go. I feel sorry to have so many children growing up uneducated."

I feel satisfied that Mr Tennant has been faithfully advising the people to send their children to the existing school, but without success, and I have thought that perhaps a little kind advice to the Indians from the Agent might help to bring about a better condition of affairs. If one school can be efficiently carried on, and all the children induced to attend, we would prefer that to the policy of two schools; but almost any course would be better than leaving the children or any considerable number of them to grow up in ignorance.

Your Obedient Servant,

The Deputy Super't General of Indian Affairs,

The Secretary:

Re application of Mr W.J. Bishop for position of teacher of Cornwall Island school.

Mr McNaughton, Public School Inspector of Cornwall writes stating that Mr Bishop possesses the requisite qualifications for teaching an Indian school. He states, however, in connection with this school that since the union of the two schools the Protestants have withheld their children from attending on the ground that it was a Roman Catholic school, and he thinks that the employment of a Protestant teacher for a few years might tend to remove that impression. He says that Mr Bishop is a Roman Catholic, whose employment might confirm the Indians in their views.

The Protestant Indians may make this an excuse for keeping their children from school, and in fact complaints have been made against the conduct of the Roman Catholic children towards the Protestant children but this school, although under the charge of a Roman Catholic teacher, is an undenominational school.

I think that a lady teacher might be able to overcome the prejudice of the Indians and might be likely to prove more successful than a man, as in the case of the St Regis school.
Should the Department wish to employ Mr Bishop there is a vacancy for a teacher for the Boys' school at Coughmawaga, where he might be appointed provisionally and where a Roman Catholic male teacher is required. The salary of the last teacher was $400.00 with a residence, but I think that a less amount might be offered to start with.

The Secretary:

Mr Inspector O'Brien in his report on the Cornwall Island school, dated the 13th ultimo, states that this school, which is in charge of Mr W.J. Bishop, is not conducted as successfully as it should be. Mr Bishop has had charge of this school for two years and although it is a difficult matter to reconcile the religious difference, this being an interdenominational school at which both Roman Catholic and Protestant children should attend, I think that had the teacher shown more energy in striving to overcome the Indians prejudices, better results could have been obtained. Mr Bishop does not reside on the Island and evidently has done very little to induce the parents to send their children. The Inspectors say the children are very backward and I think that a change after the summer holidays would be advisable, and that if a lady teacher were put in charge a better showing could be made.

Mr. Scott,

Recent reports received from the School Inspector and Agent show that the three schools on the St. Regis Reserve which are in charge of white teachers are doing excellent work and the pupils are making marked progress in their studies. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in which you state that some of the Indians on Cornwall Island claim that their children should be exempt from attending school under section 3 of the Regulations.

In reply I beg to say that the survey of this island made in 1884 shows that it is four and three-quarters miles in length and, as the school is in the centre of the island, there are only two families on the east end, Lawrence Jaco and John Garo, and four on the west end, A. Simon, P. Bing, Chas. Peters and Jos. Lear, who are outside of a two mile radius. Only children under ten years of age who live outside the two mile radius would be exempt under sub-section C of the section above referred to. Children over that age should attend school.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Carelessness is chief cause of irregular attendance; then, again, distance from the school for the little ones may be the cause, especially during unfavourable weather.

If a truant officer were appointed he might be able to improve the attendance.

The teacher seems to stress promptness, obedience and cleanliness; and to give them work in language, problems and general knowledge such as should be useful to them when they leave school. She could do much more for them if they would attend more regular; this irregular attendance handicaps the progress very much.
Sir,

I have this day caused the arrest of Peter Delormier, of Cornwall, blond, for the non attendance of two of his children at school; finding him guilty I have sentenced him to the Cornwall Jail for seven days and I hope you will concern in the action taken by me.

I have at all times ever desired by precept and example to get the Indians to send their children to school but in some cases I have met with nothing but a marked desire to keep the children out of school.

I now hope during the past few weeks, for their fires and eventually dropped into the old way, therefore I have with great reluctance decided it was for the welfare of the children to make an example of someone and I do sincerely hope that it will make the Indians realize that the children must attend school.

Sir,

At the request of the office day, I received word for the arrest of Abram Jacks of Cornwall Dale, cause non-attendance of son Abram aged 16 years past at school.

This morning, day placed him under arrest, assisted by Indian Agent, and brought him before me at Cornwall Dale, where he pled "not guilty." I took the deposition of the teacher and office day, then committed the prisoner to the Common Gaol at Cornwall Dale for ten days.

There was not any other procedure open, as he was very disagreeable, moved and sent his children to school, did not care if he went to prison for ten or twenty years, and would not pay one cent if a fine was imposed upon him. Therefore, I sentenced him as stated above.

Most assuredly he is the hardest worst case, I have ever had upon this reserve, no matter what the complaint may be.

Sir,

Loran Jocke of St. Regis called at the Department today and complained that his son, Abram Jocke, is in Cornwall Jail, sentenced by you for not sending his children to Cornwall Island School.

Loran feels that his son at this time should not be punished so severely as he is in very poor health, having just recovered from illness, and fears that a few days' confinement in jail will be serious. He states that his family is in destitute circumstances, having no provisions ahead of them; that he, Loran Jocke, had offered to pay the fine to you but was refused and referred to the Department. Loran desires that the boy be liberated upon payment of the fine or his family provided with food.

I have heard from a builder in town that he has a contract to build a school house on Cornwall Island. I was on the island today and some of the people are talking about two school houses being up. I venture to suggest to the Department that the best thing to do is to build one large school near the centre of the island or a little further to the east and engage a man to convey the children to and from the school in this way. I think the children would do better work.

Miss Lepage, the teacher, is of the same opinion, one of the serious difficulties on the island is that the parents do not send their children to school; they seem to know so little about the benefits of education and do they feel any responsibility for sending them to school? Then in the winter, once a number of them being poor they complain that they can't afford them useful clothing, if they could be called for in a crowd conveyance they would get over that difficulty—besides children would be more apt to go with the band. Then the man in charge could be employed by the Department to report them if they persisted in refusing them at home that the Department would send them to Mission schools. This is a very important matter which should receive careful consideration from the Department.

I am convinced if we are to save these people from being educated properly we must educate them.

Very sincerely yours,

A. G. Alley, Missionary

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury,

The Department has approved the transfer of Mr. Colin Chisholm from the Cornwall Island West Indian Day School (No. 309) to the new Cornwall Island East Indian Day School (No. 338), with salary at the rate of $90.00 a teaching month.

To succeed Mr. Chisholm, Miss Emily Peters has been appointed as teacher of the Cornwall Island West School (No. 309) with salary at the rate of $60 a teaching month.

Mr. Chisholm began duties at the Cornwall Island East School on February 10th, 1936, but he is entitled to salary for the full month as he had taught the Cornwall Island West School up to that date. It will be noted that his salary will be the same as it was at the Cornwall Island West School.

Miss Peters commenced duties at the Cornwall Island West School on February 10th, 1936, and she is, therefore, entitled to 20/29 of salary for February ($60 x 20/29) or $55.16.

The following entries should appear on the February paylist:

309 - Cornwall Island West - Emily Peters - General Delivery, Cornwall, Ont. - $600 - $55.16

338 - Cornwall Island East - Colin Chisholm - Cornwall, Ont. - $900 - $90.00
Ottawa, February 12, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The pay list for the current month is being prepared and, as it is understood from previous correspondence from you that Miss Peters would begin duties on the 10th instant, the Department is placing her name on the pay list.

Please let me know definitely the address to which the salary cheques of Miss Peters and Mr. Colin Chisholm should be forwarded in future.

For the month of February, cheques for both of them will be forwarded to General Delivery, Cornwall, Ont.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

D. P. McNaughton, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 24, 1919.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Froats, in a report to the Department on his recent inspection of the Cornwall Island Indian Day School, states that the school building is cold; the foundation needs a thorough repairing; the steps at the door are much dilapidated and need either new ones or thorough repairing; also that there are a number of panes of glass out and that these should be put in without delay, as there is too much cold wind pouring in over the children's heads.

You should arrange to have the necessary panes of glass put in without delay and the work done at the least possible expense.

You should also have the steps at the door repaired and placed in good condition and you should inform the Department as to what repairs are needed to the foundation of the school and the probable cost of having the work done. It is considered that, as the season is getting late, the building might be banked and any needed repairs could be made in the spring. If you consider that the banking of the school would tend to keep the building warmer, you may have this done.

Kindly give these matters your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.,

Ottawa, December 9, 1919.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of the 24th of October last, in which you were instructed to have the Cornwall Island Indian Day School banked for the winter and also a number of panes of glass put in the windows and your reply thereto of the 30th of the same month, in which you stated that you had arranged to have this work done.

The Department is informed by certain Indians of that reserve, who were here today, that the school-house is very cold, as the banking has not been properly done, also that the glass has not been put in.

I have, therefore, to request that you will have all the repairs required done to the building and the school thoroughly banked, in order to make it as comfortable as possible, and this work should be attended to at once.

The Indians protested against the enforcement of the regulations as to the regular attendance of their children, stating that, owing to the distance which the children had to travel during the cold weather, it was impossible for them to go to school. Before enforcing these regulations care should be taken to see that it will not cause hardship to any children in travelling to and from the school. In cases, however, where there is no good reason why the parents should not send their children to school the regulations should be enforced. This matter will be left to your discretion, and you should be careful to see that no undue hardship is occasioned to the children of those parents who reside at a distance from the school to compel them to attend regularly.

Your obedient servant,

F. E. Macdonald, Esq.,

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Froats, in a report to the Department on his recent inspection of the Cornwall Island Indian Day School, states that the foundation of the building and the steps at the entrance need attention. He also states that the teacher reports that the building is cold in winter and that storm windows would be helpful in keeping out the cold winds, as the windows are not in good condition. The Inspector also states that there should be a flag for the school and that the flag pole should be furnished with a rope, so that the flag can be hoisted.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish as soon as possible an estimate of the cost of having the foundation and steps repaired and storm windows put on and of the rope required for the flag pole. An early reply will oblige, in order that steps can be taken to have these repairs completed before the cold weather sets in.

A flag will be sent you from the Department for this school.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The buildings are fair only. The premises are not enclosed. There is a poor barbed wire fence to the front along the roadside. The gates are poor. There is a flag pole but no rope attached, so that the flag cannot be hoisted. The premises are stony and covered with heaps of cow manure. There are no shade trees.

Cows should not be pastured on school grounds.
Ottawa, December 11th, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Cornwall Island Indian Day School, states as follows:

"The buildings are fair only. The premises are not enclosed. There is a poor barbed wire fence to the front along the roadside. The gates are poor. There is a flag pole but no rope attached, so that the flag cannot be hoisted. The premises are stony and covered with heaps of cow manure. There are no shade trees. Cows should not be pastured on school grounds."

Please state whether in your opinion the work of erecting one of the proposed new school buildings on Cornwall Island should be proceeded with this coming spring, and if it will be possible to obtain a site. If not, you should arrange early in the spring to have the necessary repairs made to the barbed wire fence around the present school building, and the premises generally cleaned up and put in satisfactory condition.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

The buildings are in poor condition. The wood shed is small and in a better condition than are the other buildings. The water closets are small, too close together, entrances not screened properly, ventilation poor, and they are dirty. The school house is not in good condition. The teacher reports that it is quite cold. There is no proper approach to the classroom from the front, as the steps are poor and there is no way of getting in from the main road, only through the mud. The gates are poor and the school premises (grounds) are not fenced to the rear, so it is really in the corner of a cow pasture. The cows lie around the school and leave the dirty yard in a dirtier condition. I am told that the buildings are owned by the Dominion Government.

The teacher said that there were at least 50 pupils on the Island, and possibly more. There are a few at the head of the Island, attending the Public School No. 2 Township of Cornwall on the mainland; these walk across the railroad bridge and are progressing favourably in their studies.

The present school building is situated about the middle of the length of the Island, and it seems the greater populations are nearer the ends of the island - hence the distance to the school for the younger children is great. I would strongly urge that two schools be erected, one near the head, and one near the foot of the Island.

The parents are careless regarding the sending of their children to school.

Memorandum:

MR. OHR.

There is an item of $3,500 in the Supplementary Estimates for the purpose of erecting a classroom at the west end of Cornwall Island, St. Regis Reserve. Accommodation for 24 desks is required. Nearly all the children at this school carry their lunch, and, if a long cloakroom 11 or 12 ft. wide could be included in the building, it might be an advantage. This would permit of a long table with benches for the lunch hour.

The Cornwall Island Indian Day School has always been heated satisfactorily by a box stove and I believe a basement is unnecessary. The present stove can be moved to the new building, as it is in good shape.

You might note my suggestion in my memo on 33-6-8 (St. Regis Village Teachers' Residence) that both buildings be awarded in the same contract. The site on Cornwall Island is being selected by the Indian Agent and is approximately one mile from the wharf of the town of Cornwall.

Sir,

I beg to say regarding Cornwall Island School. I visited this school on Oct. 3rd./27. there were thirty-two pupils present, and Miss Mac Donald, Teacher, reports that she expects there will be forty pupils who will attend the new school when it opens. The desks in the old school, the most of them are pretty shaky, and in bad condition. I would recommend that all new single desks be placed in new school, forty in number. There will be ten small desks required for the smaller children, and thirty desks for larger ones. These desks should not arrive at Oscar Station, Cornwall Island, until the first part of the week of the 17th. October, 1927. I have made arrangements with the carpenters who are working on the new school, that if the desks arrive at Oscar Station, to have them transferred over to school, but I should be notified the day the desks should arrive, and see to this transferring myself. I will have the old desks stored away, three of them could be used at St. Regis Island school. Enclosed is a diagram of class-room, and placing of desks, which is the best to my opinion. About the stove for this school, the store in the old school is a good heater, and in good condition if it will be large enough to heat the class-room in the new school, it could be given a try. I may say that the number of pupils attending Cornwall Island School at present, is the largest on record.

I Am,
Your Obedient Servant,

W. H. Mac Gibbon
Agent.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 3rd instant, I beg to inform you that we are today placing an order with the W. F. Vilas Co., Ltd., Cowansville, P.Q., to ship the desks required for the use of the new Indian day school building on Cornwall Island. I enclose herewith a copy of our order showing the sizes of the desks ordered, the number of each size and the price quoted for supplying same. The above firm have been requested to make early shipment and to notify you of the date in order that you can arrange to accept delivery at Uscon Station.

The above firm have been requested to forward their account, in duplicate, to you, and upon receipt of the desks, if in good condition, you should certify the account in the usual manner and send it to the department in order that payment can be made.

When these desks arrive at Uscon Station, you should arrange to have them taken to the school, assembled and set up in the classroom. They should be set up in four rows, having the same size of desk in each row, with a front and rear seat.

When the building is ready, you may arrange to have the stove in the old school transferred and set up in the new building, as it is hoped that it will be satisfactory to heat the new building.

Your obedient servant,
