Sir,-

I beg to say regarding Cornwall Island old school. If this school is to be sold after the new one is completed and in working order, Ira Benedict, Indian on Cornwall Island would like to buy it; he offers $65.00, half cash, balance in ten months.

Mr. Benedict has very few buildings on his farm, if he had this old building I think it would help him considerable. Mr. Benedict is a steady worker and trying to make good.

Mr. Louis White of Cornwall Island spoke about wanting to buy this school, but Mr. White has lots of buildings, and I would say that Ira Benedict should have the chance to buy it.

I am,

Ottawa, October 27, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, relative to the sale of the present old school building on the Cornwall Island Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that when the new school building is ready for occupation and the old furnishings, etc., removed, the Department will approve of your arranging for the sale of the old building. If Ira Benedict will pay the sum of $40 in cash, and agree to remove the building and level up the foundation on which it stands and also clean up all materials, the Department will approve of the sale to him of this old building. It is considered that the above amount, along with the work in levelling the site, is a fair charge. You should, however, obtain the above amount from Benedict before he takes possession of the building, as well as his promise to level the site, and you should forward the amount received to the Department for credit of the Receiver General. I shall be pleased to hear us to whether he agrees to purchase the building and do the work mentioned for the sum of $40.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

Cornwall Island, Indian Day School.

On visiting this school on the 24th ultimo, Mr. Chisholm, took up the matter with me in regard to providing a slide for the school children. Mr. Chisholm thought that a slide could be made with very little cost. Mr. Paul Caldwell, caretaker of the school, is willing to provide the timber, two long skids, about 30 or 40 feet long, and supports, and is asking $4.00 for this material.

In addition to this, there would be the lumber for the slide, possibly $6.00 or $7.00 would purchase the required lumber. Mr. Chisholm would erect the slide with the help of the older school boys, so there would be no cost to the erecting of the slide. Mr. Chisholm is doing good work on the island, and would recommend this slide supplied.

In previous years, this school has been allowed $5.00 to purchase Christmas Gifts for the school children. Mr. Chisholm says that this amount is too small for the number of pupils attending school, and requests that this amount be increased to $7.00.

Will you please advise me in these matters.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, regarding the providing of a slide for the pupils of the Cornwall Island Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of two long skids and the other lumber required to erect the slide. It is noted that the cost of the material would not exceed the sum of $12. The teacher and the older boys are to erect the slide without cost to the Department. You may forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the two long skids and for the other materials required, the total cost of which should be kept within the amount mentioned by you. The teacher should be responsible to see that no injury is occasioned to any of the pupils in the use of the slide.

Regarding the grant to purchase gifts for the pupils at Christmas, I have to say that you may incur an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $7 for this purpose. Dear Sir,

There is a well-drilling machine on Cornwall Island at present. I was speaking to a man in connection with it and he said that they could drill a well for $2.75 per foot. They supply the piping. Perhaps we could get them to dig it a bit cheaper.

We need a well very badly at Cornwall Island School. The closest well is at a little over 300 yds away. It is an open well, near a barn and without a pump. The water is not very good. It is rather dangerous for the children to get water there too.

Please write and let me know whether you would consider drilling a well or not.

Yours truly,
Colin Chisholm, teacher.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

I wrote to Mr. Mac Gibbon, agent, a few days ago asking if the Department would drill a well on Cornwall Island. I have been speaking to a number of Indians since and I asked them if they would be willing to give one day free charge to dig a well and they said they would.

I intend holding a meeting at the school some night to arrange about this matter. I am sure they will all help a little. I told them that if you would allow any money I would divide it evenly among everyone that will help.

Of course we will need a little money for to buy stones if they charge and for other incidentals.

(next page)
How much would you be willing to spend on a well for the school? I will not have the meeting I mentioned until I hear from you. Please let me know as soon as possible.

Yours truly,
Colin Thisholm, teacher.
Ottawa, December 6th, 1933.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo, with reference to drilling a well at the Cornwall Island Indian Day School. Mr. Agent MacGibbon brought this matter to the attention of the Department in a letter dated the 16th ultimo and he was informed on November 23rd that, owing to lack of funds, it is not possible to consider drilling a well at the present time.

I note from your recent letter that the Indians are prepared to do most of the work without cost. Please ascertain accurately what expenditure the Department would be required to provide. You should forward this information to Mr. Agent MacGibbon and he will report to the Department; when the matter will be reconsidered.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
Acting Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to report a Council meeting held at St Regis Que. on Monday October lst.

The Council resolved that they should request the Department to provide means of conveying the children living on the east end of Cornwall Island to the Cornwall Island school.

Referring to Resolution No.2. That they should request the Department to provide means of conveying the children living on the east end of Cornwall Island to the Cornwall Island school. I understand that there are 15 or more children of school age living at the east end of the Island, which is about four miles from the present school. A man, and team could be hired for $2.00 per day to drive these children to and from the Cornwall Island school providing that the school was furnished with extra seats and desks to accommodate the extra pupils.

Dear Sir,

I am pleased to inform you that I had a letter recently from Mr. Scott. He was visiting the Department of Indian Affairs and I wished him to make a visit to Cornwall Island. He promised to be here on the 21st April for the day.

I mentioned to Mr. McNaughton our desire to have him visit. Mr. Scott wrote back that he would be visiting on the 21st April and would try to do his best to fit in a meeting at the school house. We met up with him at the Centre of the Island, where we could have our Church for the meeting, which is the Centre of the Island.

I hope Mr. McNaughton will call on me so we can talk more together.

Mr. Scott is a most competent man for his work and I am hoping for a full house.

I am respectfully,

Dear Sir,

It appears from this letter that you have arranged for an agricultural meeting on Cornwall Island without consulting the Indian Agent. Is this correct? Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter, No. 33-4-5, of the 1st inst., Re-arranging for meeting without consulting the Indian Agent, I beg to explain that on January 3rd, 1936, I received the following letter from the Department—

"I am today in receipt of a communication from Rev. A. Galley of Cornwall, in which he speaks in most appreciative terms of the benefit to the Indians of your visit to Cornwall Island. He asks that you visit them again and I think it well if you could include it in the itinerary of your next eastern visit. You might communicate direct with Mr. Galley.

Not having the Agent's Address, I communicated as directed with Mr. Galley, supposing that he would arrange with the Agent for Agricultural meetings afternoon, and evening of Apr., the 28th, I received word, in answer, to the effect that he would take the matter up with the Agent and let me know. I expected the Agent to send me a letter but evidently he wrote to the Department for permission to use the School House. I hope the Agent will not feel that we ignored him, in this connection. We have always been careful, in all our work to acknowledge the position and authority of the Indian Agents. I think, now as I have the address of the Agent for the first, in your letter, I will write him an explanatory letter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dept., Ind., Affs.,

Dear Sir:

This school is in need of painting both inside and out. The interior will require a thorough washing before paint can be applied; it will depend on appearances after first coat, whether second coat will be required.

The exterior will require two coats to give a good appearing finish. This school is situated within full view of International highway.

Estimated cost 2 coats, inside and out paint brushes etc. $70.00, labour $45.00. Louie David, who is recommended as a good painter, will do the work at 25¢ per hour. Please advise regarding this matter so I can have the work started as soon as possible.

Dear Sir:

Well school grounds

With reference to your letter asking for an estimate of the cost of digging a well on the lot of the Cornwall Island, west, Indian Bay school.

There should be a well supplied for use of the school children. At present they get their drinking water from the well belonging to a neighbor farmer. This well is located near his barn and is not properly covered to exclude surface water.

The cost of digging a well depends upon the depth it is found necessary to go to secure a good supply of water. We may strike water at from 20' to 35', with the cost increasing the deeper you go, all depending on the nature of the earth removed.

It cost to dig and stone the Cornwall Island, east, Indian Day school well $124.00, contract by the Pt.

I can have this well dug and stoned by competent Indian labour, by the hour. I would have to purchase necessary equipment, such as derrick, bucket, pulley and rope. Three men with a team at 5¢ per hour for the men, 35¢ per hour men and team.

I enclose an estimate of approximate cost of a well dug 30' and stoned inclusive of cement covering and including a pump and piping.

I am enclosing a contract signed by Tobias Thompson of Cornwall Island, who agrees to dig and stone a well install a suitable pump and necessary piping. Also a proper cement covering.

All matters considered I think we could not do better than grant the contract to Mr. Thompson. It is all problematical how he makes out.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from Inspector's report on the Cornwall Island West Indian Day School visited on May 20, 1942:

Mr. Caldwell transports Miss Peters and 12 of the oldest pupils to the East End School for a half-day session per week at which time Miss Peters teaches Home Economics to the girls of both schools while Mr. Chisholm takes Manual Training in the basement with the boys. While Mr. Caldwell has been receiving only 75¢ per half-day for this service, I was given to understand that he would only continue the service if he received $1.00. I beg leave to recommend that the increase of 25¢ per round trip be paid to Mr. Caldwell.

The girls have made such excellent progress in cooking, hand-sewing, etc., that it is urgently recommended that a good second-hand sewing machine be bought for the East End School.

St. Regis, Que.,
July 27, 1944.

Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division.

I must advise that the floor in the coal bin at the Cornwall Island West School needs repairs. This shed is annexed to the main building but without any cement foundation, hence it is off the ground about three feet. There are no centre supports to take the strain off the sills and consequently, the latter have broken.

It will be necessary to get five 2" x 8" x 12' planks, remove the coal and wood from the shed; get jacks and raise the floor to its proper level and install new sills. I can't say for sure yet but I hardly think it will be necessary to put in any new flooring. It is expected the labour cost will be around $35.00. I may have to rent a couple of jacks as I have nothing here to work with. May we proceed with the work?

T. L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.

Perhaps you have other plans for this school, hence above will be held back pending your reply.

Sept. 8th, 1944

R. A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training.

Please be advised that on the morning of Sept. 5th, a survey was made to ascertain any visible damage to school buildings as a result of the earthquake during the early hours of that morning.

Our schools in general do not appear to have suffered damage to the extent of having to close any of them. As far as getting any repairs done for some time at least, I am at a loss to know where to look for help along this line as it is out of the question to get any locally or in the neighbourhood as every available mason, bricklayer and plasterer is engaged in Cornwall trying to patch things up there before the cold weather sets in.

Cornwall Ild. West school appears to have fared the worst. Foundation is cracked in several places (but there is no cellar here). The south wall of the classroom should be replastered as well as parts of the north wall over the blackboards. The boys and girls cloakrooms need repairing. The chimney is cracked in two at roof level but due to the cement over the bricks the extent of damage cannot be known as yet... Approximately one-half of the S. east wall needs replastering.

Cornwall Ild.-E. school chimney is cracked vertically from top to bottom. This chimney is set in flush with the east wall and I cannot say what damage is done, if any, beyond what is visible. It may be that a filler is all that is required here. As far as the other schools are concerned and residences, things appear to be fairly good. Due to being practically on the go for three days and nights I have not as yet been able to get to St. Regis Island but have contacted Mr. Thompson, where the teacher lives, and he tells me no serious damage occurred.

p.t.o.
While up to this writing tremors are still being felt, unless we get another severe rocking, I do not expect further damage will result. Teachers have been advised to clear their classrooms should any tremors be felt during school hours.

T.L. Bonnah
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 14, 1944.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Que.

Re: Damage by Earthquake,
to Indian Day Schools,
St. Regis Agency.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 8 and have noticed with the utmost interest the information sent forward by you. It would appear at this date that our schools have escaped serious damage.

I can readily appreciate the difficulty you are likely to experience in securing the help necessary to make even urgent repairs, in view of conditions in Cornwall. This letter will be your authority to exercise your own best judgment in respect to the urgent repairs that should be undertaken when labour is available.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
R. A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training.

I have been requested by Mrs. White, teacher of the Cornwall Island West School, to try and solve a housing problem which has confronted her. As you probably know she has been living with her mother on Cornwall Island and up until recently matters have been going along fairly well. The fact that all but our two Indian teachers are provided for in that respect does not help the situation any and has in the past provided much room for discussion amongst the natives.

However, to aggravate Mrs. White's problem, her sister's husband died recently and she and her three children have been forced to return with the mother to live. They have no means of support and another child is expected shortly. Which means that in such a small home, Mrs. White will have to get out. There is no suitable vacancy existing in an Indian home within reasonable distance from the school where she can stay. There is a small house owned by Johnny Thompson just across the NYC tracks off the highway. This house is rented but Mr. Thompson advises he would rent it to us to supply accommodation for one or two teachers at $12.00 per month. He will, however, have to lay another floor and is agreeable to do this if he is advised in time that it will be rented as a teachers residence. We would, however, have to supply some fuel and a limited amount of furnishings and possibly a small cook stove. It would appear that whether or not Mrs. White continues to teach on Cornwall Island a residence will be needed as it is very doubtful if a lady teacher could stand the trip to Cornwall across the bridge especially during winter months, that is of course, should the idea of a teacher living in Cornwall be entertained. May I have your views on this matter at an early date.

T.L. Hannah, Agent.
Ottawa, September 14, 1944.

Mr. I. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Que.

Re: Teacher's Residence,
Cornwall Island School

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant and have noted with interest the suggestion submitted therein.

In view of all the circumstances, I am disposed to recommend that the house owned by Johnny Thompson be rented as a teacherage, provided that the rent asked by Thompson is in your judgment reasonable. It may be necessary also, as you state, to supply certain furnishings. A list of these, with the approximate cost, should be submitted in due course. Care should be taken, of course, to see that this house is reasonably comfortable.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R. A. Hody, Supt. Welfare & Training

On a recent visit to the Cornwall Island West School, Mrs. White pointed out the very unsatisfactory conditions existing with respect to storage space for school supplies. These supplies are at present piled around the room on benches and desks, which gives a littered appearance to the school, and does not protect the books and papers sufficiently. Mrs. White needs a cabinet constructed on the back wall of the school room to house these supplies.

If authorization for the construction of such a cabinet can be obtained, it could probably be done by local labor for around $35. The limited space in this school house has been forced to accommodate a much larger class than usual this year, and the supplies are accumulating to such an extent that it is difficult to find a place to operate for ordinary class work.

Your early attention to this matter will be greatly appreciated.

dated June 7, 1945, on:

CORNWALL ISLAND WEST INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Here, we find 49 children, all due to return next September, with six more, of school age, to enter for the next school year; such an attendance likely due to the Family Allowance Act.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON ST. REGIS AGENCY

Maintainence of Buildings:
While the schools were closed for the summer months it was possible to have considerable plaster work done, and much of the damage caused by the previous earthquakes has now been repaired. Repairs have been made to the porches of the Cornwall Island West School, the interior of the classroom redecorated, a new toilet was also constructed. Both cloakrooms as well as an entire wall of the school had to be replastered before any decorating could be done. In the Village, the Senior room of the Village school has been redecorated, giving it a much brighter appearance. Plaster work and some decorating have already been done at the Teachers' Residence in the Village.

During extreme high winds some time ago, the girl's toilet at Cornwall Island West School tipped over. It has been set up and minor repairs made. It cannot, however, be put in satisfactory condition and a new building will have to be constructed. As I am unable to get carpenters on the Reserve now, I would like authorization to have a toilet made up at Hodgins Lumber Co., in Cornwall and transported to the school. This would cost us in the neighbourhood of Sixty-five dollars ($65.00). I do not think we have exceeded the amount originally authorized for school repairs and the above method would be the most economical way to rectify this situation.

May we hear from you at an early date, please.

T. L. Bonnah,
